Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Systematics of a pantropical diversification: the suboscine passerine birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's finches of the Gal√°pagos Islands stand as one of the most impressive examples of evolution. After colonizing the islands, a single ancestral finch species eventually diversified into 13 species of different sizes, bill shapes, and ecologies. The suboscine passerine birds exhibit a similar history, but their diversification was not limited to a small set of islands; instead they are found throughout South America, Central America, North America, and parts of the Old World. There are now 1,300 species that differ dramatically in body shape and size, feeding behavior, and nest architecture. The primary goal of this project is to use DNA sequences to reconstruct the evolutionary history of these species, and to use this model system to investigate why the tropics are so biologically diverse.

A vital component of this collaborative project between U.S. and Brazilian scientists is the research training it will provide. With fieldwork planned in Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Malaysia, Venezuela, and Viet Nam, young scientists from a diversity of countries will be exposed not only to a diversity of natural environments but will also interact and forge relationships with their international peers. By working together to reconstruct perhaps the most spectacular evolutionary radiations of birds in the world, the researchers will learn how evolution works on a continental scale while training a new generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chances are if you go outside right now you will see a wild bird. Depending on where you live, the bird species you are most likely to see will differ. For example, in North America, the most common neighborhood birds belong to a group of birds known as oscine passerines. In Central and South America, the most common birds belong to a group known as suboscine passerines. Passerines are the largest order of birds and among the most diverse orders of terrestrial vertebrates. The suboscines group includes more than 1,306 species, and in the Neotropics, they make up roughly one-third of the total avian species richness. The primary goal of our project was to use genomic data to reconstruct a tree of life for the approximately 1,300 species of suboscine birds.

We used genomic data to reconstruct a tree of life that traces the history of all suboscine species. We were particularly interested in understanding why some geographic regions have more species than others. Most biological diversity originated in tropical regions, some of which are considered by scientists as hotspots for diversity. However, due to limited sampling, our knowledge of tropical diversity remains incomplete. Thus, it is difficult for researchers to answer the fundamental questions of the mechanisms that drive and maintain diversity. To address this, our international team of scientists produced the first complete, species-level phylogeny of a major group of tropical birds.

We assembled a comprehensive data set of 1,940 suboscine samples, which represented 1,287 of the 1,306 suboscine species. The genetic samples were obtained from specimens housed in 21 museums around the world. Museum scientists began collecting genetic samples approximately 40 years ago, and thanks to those efforts, the team was able to pursue this project. Using genetic markers scattered across the entire genome, the team described the evolutionary history of suboscines and created a framework for further questions about mechanisms that drive species diversity.

Our project began in 2012 when institutions from North and South America united on the quest to build a species-level phylogeny of the suboscines using genomic data. Our project became increasingly urgent as these same tropical regions that shelter and produce such diversity are under rapidly intensifying human pressure and decline. 

Our study revealed a paradox of suboscine diversity – that new species actually form faster in coldspots than hotspots. Coldspots are not actually cold, but are places like deserts and mountaintops that are relatively species-poor with a lot of opportunities, giving new species the elbow room to evolve. In contrast, hotspots like the Amazon are the result of the gradual accumulation of species over a long time. This paradox is a relatively new concept learned from comparing tropical vs. temperate regions, and our project was the first to uncover it using a complete species-level phylogeny of a primarily tropical radiation.

We concluded that conservation efforts to save the rapidly changing tropical landscapes need to focus not only on the species-rich Amazon but also on regions that are less diverse but contribute disproportionally to the generation of new species. The paradox of diversity in suboscines was revealed because of the dozens of natural history museums and museum researchers working for decades in tough conditions on shoestring budgets to document the rapidly disappearing diversity of the tropics.  We sampled an incredible amount of diversity - roughly one out of every three species of birds in the American tropics. We were only able to do this project because of the hard work of numerous local scientists who have dedicated their lives to studying and preserving this diversity. Samples for this project came from museum specimens, some that dated as far back as the early eighteen and nineteen hundreds that included rare, endangered, and extinct species.

Today, eight years after the project began, our research team has grown to mimic the diversity of the suboscines. Many of the researchers involved in our study are from Latin America (Colombia, Brazil, Uruguay, and Venezuela), and recent teams fielded by the renowned Museum of Natural Science at Louisiana State University to obtain samples like those used in this study were women-led efforts. Our paper marks not only a change in our understanding of evolution in the tropics but also in acknowledgement and valuation of the diversity of culture, expertise, and perspective in the field of ornithology. The undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers who contributed to this project received mentorship in a diversity of areas. They got to experience the dynamics of managing a large-scale international collaborative project. They learned all facets of executing a research project, from experimental design to publishing manuscripts detailing results. Most importantly, they received training in critical thinking that will serve them in whichever career path they choose.
